questiontext.text:
Part of the question has been solved for you. Complete the remaining bit and enter the answer:

Question

Consider the problem of determining the temperature distribution in a thin homogeneous bar of length L, given the initial temperature throughout the bar and the temperature at both ends at all times. The governing equation is:

$$ \small \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \beta^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} $$ (1)

where $$ \small \beta = \sqrt{K/c ho} $$

Boundary Conditions:

i) $$ \small u(0,t) = 0 $$

ii) $$ \small u(L,t) = 0 $$

Initial Condition:

i) $$ \small u(x,0) = f(x) $$

Given:

$$ \small f(x) = -\frac{8\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$ (2)

Look for solutions of the form

$$ \small u(x,t)=T(t)X(x) $$ (3)

Solution

Rewriting the governing equation using (3),

$$ \small \frac{1}{\beta} \frac{T'(t)}{T(t)} = \frac{X''(x)}{X(x)} = \alpha $$ (4)

Case 1 - $$ \small \alpha $$ > 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = \lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = \lambda^{2}X => X(x) = Ae^{\lambda x} + Be^{-\lambda x} $$

Applying boundary condition (i) and (ii) will show that this case results in a trivial solution.

Case 2 - $$ \small \alpha $$ < 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = -\lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = -\lambda^2X => X(x) = A\cos{\lambda x} + B \sin{\lambda x} $$

From boundary condition (i)

$$ \small u(0,t) = 0 => X(0) = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore $$ A = 0

From boundary condition (ii)

$$ \small u(L,t) = 0 => B \sin{\lambda L} = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore \small \lambda L = n\pi $$

$$ \small\lambda = \frac{n\pi}{L} $$

$$ \small X_n = B_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}[L}} $$

Also,

$$ \small T_n(t) = D_n exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

$$ \small u_n(x,t) = c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

To satisfy the initial condition we use the superposition principle, i.e, :

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

Thus at $$ \small t $$ = 0, we get

$$ \small u(x,0) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} = f(x) = -\frac{8\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$

This is a half-range Fourier series expression. Solve it to find an expression for $$ \small u(x,t) $$. Use L = 10 and $$ \small \beta $$ = 1.

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} [?] $$

Enter the ($$ \small ? $$) missing expression in the box below.

generalfeedback.text:
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$
This is a half-range Fourier series, so;
$$ \small c_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_{0}^{L} [-\frac{-8x^2}{L^2}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})+\frac{10x}{L}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})]dx $$
Solving the integral
$$ \small c_n = \frac{16\, \left(4\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 + {\pi}^2\, n^2\, \left(2\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 - 1\right)\right)}{{\pi}^3\, n^3} $$
If n is even,
$$ \small c_n = -\frac{16}{\pi\, n} $$
Substituting back into expression for u(x,t):
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} -\frac{16\, \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{{\pi}^2\, \beta^2\, (2n)^2\, t}{L^2}}\, \sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, (2n)\, x}{L}\right)}{\pi\, (2n)}$$

ii) $$ \small u(L,t) = 0 $$

Initial Condition:

i) $$ \small u(x,0) = f(x) $$

Given:

$$ \small f(x) = -\frac{2\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$ (2)

Look for solutions of the form

$$ \small u(x,t)=T(t)X(x) $$ (3)

Solution

Rewriting the governing equation using (3),

$$ \small \frac{1}{\beta} \frac{T'(t)}{T(t)} = \frac{X''(x)}{X(x)} = \alpha $$ (4)

Applying boundary condition (i) and (ii) will show that this case results in a trivial solution.

Case 2 - $$ \small \alpha $$ < 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = -\lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = -\lambda^2X => X(x) = A\cos{\lambda x} + B \sin{\lambda x} $$

From boundary condition (i)

$$ \small u(0,t) = 0 => X(0) = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore $$ A = 0

From boundary condition (ii)

$$ \small u(L,t) = 0 => B \sin{\lambda L} = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore \small \lambda L = n\pi $$

$$ \small\lambda = \frac{n\pi}{L} $$

$$ \small X_n = B_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}[L}} $$

Also,

$$ \small T_n(t) = D_n exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

$$ \small u_n(x,t) = c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

To satisfy the initial condition we use the superposition principle, i.e, :

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

Thus at $$ \small t $$ = 0, we get

$$ \small u(x,0) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} = f(x) = -\frac{2\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$

This is a half-range Fourier series expression. Solve it to find an expression for $$ \small u(x,t) $$. Use L = 10 and $$ \small \beta $$ = 1.

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} [?] $$

Enter the ($$ \small ? $$) missing expression in the box below.

generalfeedback.text:
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$
This is a half-range Fourier series, so;
$$ \small c_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_{0}^{L} [-\frac{-2x^2}{L^2}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})+\frac{4x}{L}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})]dx $$
Solving the integral
$$ \small c_n = \frac{4\, \left(4\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 + {\pi}^2\, n^2\, \left(2\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 - 1\right)\right)}{{\pi}^3\, n^3} $$
If n is even,
$$ \small c_n = -\frac{4}{\pi\, n} $$
Substituting back into expression for u(x,t):
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} -\frac{4\, \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{{\pi}^2\, \beta^2\, (2n)^2\, t}{L^2}}\, \sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, (2n)\, x}{L}\right)}{\pi\, (2n)}$$

Question

Consider the problem of determining the temperature distribution in a thin homogeneous bar of length L, given the initial temperature throughout the bar and the temperature at both ends at all times. The governing equation is:

$$ \small \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \beta^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} $$ (1)

where $$ \small \beta = \sqrt{K/c ho} $$

Boundary Conditions:

i) $$ \small u(0,t) = 0 $$

ii) $$ \small u(L,t) = 0 $$

Initial Condition:

i) $$ \small u(x,0) = f(x) $$

Given:

$$ \small f(x) = -\frac{6\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 4\right)}{L} $$ (2)

Look for solutions of the form

$$ \small u(x,t)=T(t)X(x) $$ (3)

Solution

Rewriting the governing equation using (3),

$$ \small \frac{1}{\beta} \frac{T'(t)}{T(t)} = \frac{X''(x)}{X(x)} = \alpha $$ (4)

Case 1 - $$ \small \alpha $$ > 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = \lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = \lambda^{2}X => X(x) = Ae^{\lambda x} + Be^{-\lambda x} $$

Applying boundary condition (i) and (ii) will show that this case results in a trivial solution.

Case 2 - $$ \small \alpha $$ < 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = -\lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = -\lambda^2X => X(x) = A\cos{\lambda x} + B \sin{\lambda x} $$

From boundary condition (i)

$$ \small u(0,t) = 0 => X(0) = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore $$ A = 0

From boundary condition (ii)

$$ \small u(L,t) = 0 => B \sin{\lambda L} = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore \small \lambda L = n\pi $$

$$ \small\lambda = \frac{n\pi}{L} $$

$$ \small X_n = B_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}[L}} $$

Also,

$$ \small T_n(t) = D_n exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

$$ \small u_n(x,t) = c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

To satisfy the initial condition we use the superposition principle, i.e, :

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

Thus at $$ \small t $$ = 0, we get

$$ \small u(x,0) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} = f(x) = -\frac{6\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 4\right)}{L} $$

This is a half-range Fourier series expression. Solve it to find an expression for $$ \small u(x,t) $$. Use L = 10 and $$ \small \beta $$ = 1.

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} [?] $$

Question

Consider the problem of determining the temperature distribution in a thin homogeneous bar of length L, given the initial temperature throughout the bar and the temperature at both ends at all times. The governing equation is:

$$ \small \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = \beta^2 \frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} $$ (1)

where $$ \small \beta = \sqrt{K/c ho} $$

Boundary Conditions:

i) $$ \small u(0,t) = 0 $$

ii) $$ \small u(L,t) = 0 $$

Initial Condition:

i) $$ \small u(x,0) = f(x) $$

Given:

$$ \small f(x) = -\frac{8\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$ (2)

Look for solutions of the form

$$ \small u(x,t)=T(t)X(x) $$ (3)

Solution

Rewriting the governing equation using (3),

$$ \small \frac{1}{\beta} \frac{T'(t)}{T(t)} = \frac{X''(x)}{X(x)} = \alpha $$ (4)

Case 1 - $$ \small \alpha $$ > 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = \lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = \lambda^{2}X => X(x) = Ae^{\lambda x} + Be^{-\lambda x} $$

Applying boundary condition (i) and (ii) will show that this case results in a trivial solution.

Case 2 - $$ \small \alpha $$ < 0

Let: $$ \small \alpha = -\lambda^2 $$

$$ \small X' = -\lambda^2X => X(x) = A\cos{\lambda x} + B \sin{\lambda x} $$

From boundary condition (i)

$$ \small u(0,t) = 0 => X(0) = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore $$ A = 0

From boundary condition (ii)

$$ \small u(L,t) = 0 => B \sin{\lambda L} = 0 $$

$$ \tiny \therefore \small \lambda L = n\pi $$

$$ \small\lambda = \frac{n\pi}{L} $$

$$ \small X_n = B_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}[L}} $$

Also,

$$ \small T_n(t) = D_n exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

$$ \small u_n(x,t) = c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

To satisfy the initial condition we use the superposition principle, i.e, :

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$

Thus at $$ \small t $$ = 0, we get

$$ \small u(x,0) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n \sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}} = f(x) = -\frac{8\, x\, \sin\!\left(\frac{n\, p\, x}{L}\right)\, \left(\frac{x}{L} - 2\right)}{L} $$

This is a half-range Fourier series expression. Solve it to find an expression for $$ \small u(x,t) $$. Use L = 10 and $$ \small \beta $$ = 1.

$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} [?] $$

Enter the ($$ \small ? $$) missing expression in the box below.

generalfeedback.text:
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} u_n(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} c_n\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}exp [-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{L^2} \beta^{2} t] $$
This is a half-range Fourier series, so;
$$ \small c_n = \frac{2}{L} \int_{0}^{L} [-\frac{-8x^2}{L^2}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})+\frac{10x}{L}sin(\frac{n\pi x}{L})]dx $$
Solving the integral
$$ \small c_n = \frac{16\, \left(4\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 + {\pi}^2\, n^2\, \left(2\, {\sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, n}{2}\right)}^2 - 1\right)\right)}{{\pi}^3\, n^3} $$
If n is even,
$$ \small c_n = -\frac{16}{\pi\, n} $$
Substituting back into expression for u(x,t):
$$ \small u(x,t) = \sum_{{n}={1}}^{\infty} -\frac{16\, \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{{\pi}^2\, \beta^2\, (2n)^2\, t}{L^2}}\, \sin\!\left(\frac{\pi\, (2n)\, x}{L}\right)}{\pi\, (2n)}$$
